title.narrative: Boreal Avian Modelling Project, Phase IV

description.narrative: The Boreal Avian Modeling Project is a collaboration of industry, academic, government, and non-government researchers throughout North America building a scientific foundation for management of bird species. Phase IV of the project seeks to understand range-wide population dynamics of migratory birds. This research will support regional and national initiatives in avian conservation and monitoring, including full life cycle modeling. The project will quantify effects of boreal land-use change on breeding populations, quantify the effects of inter-annual variation in weather on regional abundances, and evaluate the potential for detecting regional population trends using the sparse data available in the boreal region.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

Phase IV of the project seeks to understand range-wide population dynamics of migratory birds. This research will support regional and national initiatives in avian conservation and monitoring, including full life cycle modeling. title.narrative: Boreal Avian Modelling Project, Phase IV

description.narrative: This 4th phase project will build the foundation for the management of the region's avifauna.This work will estimate national and regional population consequences of disturbances; describe spatial patterns of inter-annual variability in boreal bird populations; assess potential to detect trends in boreal populations using sparse data; continue partnership with the Canadian Boreal Forest Agreement (CBFA); and develop an online mapping tool to enable users to explore BAM model results and data products.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Habitat Management to Conserve the Sprague's Pipit II PP

description.narrative: Spragues Pipit breed exclusively in the northern Great Plains. They are habitat specialists that require patches of relatively tall, native grass cover. Largely due to land conversion, less than 18% of the grassland in the breeding range of the Spragues Pipit remains. This project will build on a previous grant to create critical habitat for the pipit through modified grazing management, working with willing land managers. The grantee will improve the habitat by deferment of grazing (3,590 acres); compare the pipit's use of those lands to nearby controls; and provide outreach to ranchers and agencies on management options to conserve this important migratory species. The long-term goal of this project is to provide enough habitat to reverse the pipits decline in population locally, increasing the estimated population by a minimum of 1% (approximately 800 individuals).

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: Habitat Management to Conserve the Sprague's Pipit II PP

description.narrative: This project will create critical habitat for the Spragues Pipit through modified grazing management with willing land managers in the northern Great Plains. This project will defer grazing to 1,453 ha of Spragues Pipit habitat, manage and restore 1,534 ha of habitat, and conduct research and monitoring on 4,245 ha.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

description.narrative: U.S. Fish and Wildlife (Service) staff will work cooperatively with the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies (AFWA) to develop and implement a range of science development, implementation, and coordination activities as described in the statement of work submitted with the application. Specifically, the Service participates in the semi-annual science coordination meetings with other federal agencies and AFWA to prioritize the activities of AFWA Science Coordination Team, based on input from various Service program areas and other agencies in their ongoing activities and science needs, review performance on recent activities, and revise tactics and strategies as necessary to meet goals. Based on identified goals and strategies from these coordination meetings, Service staff from various program areas work with the AFWA science staff to implement these science strategies via various cooperative Federal/State/Private teams and committees including the FWS Climate Change Team, the North American Bird Conservation Initiative, National Fish Habitat Action Plan, the AFWA Science and Research Committee, Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation, the Endangered Species Task Force, and the National Invasive Species Council.

description.narrative: New York City Audubon Society will execute its beach-nesting and migratory shorebird program, which aims to ..protect these birds and their habitats in New York City. Funding will help support migratory and beach-nesting ..shorebird monitoring, a city-wide Shorebird Blitz, citizen science horseshoe crab monitoring, beach outreach in ..local communities, an education program centered around shorebirds, and 2 beach cleanups. Partners will ..expand their research into the migration of Semipalmated Sandpipers using VHF NanoTag technology, filling in ..important information gaps, and conduct research on productivity of Piping Plovers and American ..Oystercatchers nesting in close proximity. All activities seek to increase knowledge of how birds use New York City.. as nesting and stopover habitat, to improve habitat, and to increase awareness and stewardship for these birds.

description.narrative: The Nature Conservancy in Iowa (TNC) will acquire the 506-acre Green Hill Ranch, in the nationally significant ..Loess Hills region of western Iowa. The Loess Hills is an area with extensive grassland and savanna woodland ..habitat important for breeding birds and migrating species. The Green Hill Ranch acquisition is a rare opportunity to ..acquire and protect a significant amount of land and habitat in the Loess Hills, just outside the Omaha-Council Bluffs ..metropolitan. The project will build upon conservation successes by TNC and partners and establish a complex of ..conserved lands in the southern Loess Hills.

description.narrative: This project will permanently eliminate development opportunities on 48,817 acres of shortgrass prairie grassland ..habitat and riparian areas. This property is used extensively by several species of Neotropical migratory birds. This ..project focuses on two primary objectives, (1) permanently protect 48,817 acres of grassland habitat and riparian ..areas; and (2) incentivize additional conservation opportunities with neighboring landowners. These objectives will ..be met through the acquisition of a permanent conservation easement on the JE Canyon Ranch. Neighboring ..landowners often initiate projects following the completion of a successful conservation transaction. CCALT intends..to use the JE Canyon Ranch transaction as a demonstration project for this region.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Combating Wildlife Trafficking by Improving Understanding of Impacts and Drivers to Help Reduce Demand for Illegal Wildlife Products in the Greater Seattle Area

description.narrative: This project will assess citizen knowledge of wildlife trafficking in the greater Seattle, Washington area by targeting the one million seasonal cruise ship passengers using the Port of Seattle and the over one million yearly visitors to Woodland Park Zoo. This project is intended to help conserve two groups of species - globally iconic species threatened by illegal wildlife trafficking as identified by Washington States Initiative 1401 (such as tigers, elephants, and rhinos), and key threatened species from Alaskas illegal wildlife trade (such as walrus and whales) by addressing consumer demand. Specific project components include: 1) to collect and assess existing information (including through citizen surveys and through working with USFWS Law Enforcement and other agencies) on wildlife trafficking in and around Seattle to determine the types and scale of the trade, the particular species involved in the trade, the consumer groups involved, and the factors influencing their current attitudes/behavior; 2) develop strategic and focused education and behavior change initiatives focused on the Seattle cruise ship industry and Woodland Park Zoo, and 3) evaluate the effectiveness of these awareness-building activities and messaging.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Combatting Wildlife Trafficking by Improveing Understanding of Impacts and Drivers to Help Reduce Demand for Illegal Wildlife products in the Greater Seattle Area

description.narrative: Reduce demand for illegal wildlife products in the greater Seattle area and Alaska by improving current understanding of the drivers of wildlife trafficking in and around the greater Seattle area, as well as consumers understanding of the issues. Increase cruise passenger awareness of illegal wildlife products in Alaska and their ability to identify the difference between legal and illegally sourced products or handicrafts.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: Many North American shorebird species are declining at alarming rates and it is not known why. Analyses of data collected by the Arctic Shorebird Demographics Network (ASDN) showed annual survival rates of adult shorebirds are generally robust at Arctic breeding sites and that conditions on migratory stopover or overwintering sites are likely driving annual survival rates. Partners began a multi-year study in 2017 to deploy tracking devices to determine where birds go once they leave the breeding grounds. This proposal requests funds to better understand movements of birds across the entire ranges of the species. Partners will focus on American Golden-Plover and Red Phalarope, two Neotropical migrants both declining and facing imminent threats that can only be resolved by learning where and when the species migrate in more detail than is currently known. In Alaska and Canada, partners will deploy recently developed, light-weight GPS-Argos and PTT-Argos tag technology with the ability to indicate bird location very accurately. These locations reflect the habitat preferences of the species and can be geo-referenced with landscape features to assess the local threats. Once this information is known, conservation actions can be targeted at these sites and these efforts will lead to increased conservation success.

description.narrative: The Nature Conservancy in Iowa (TNC) requests $200,000 to be matched by $600,000 in private funds to acquire the 167-acre Steele Family Limited Partnership in the Little Sioux Watershed of northwest Iowa. The Little Sioux Watershed is an area with extensive grassland and savanna habitat important for breeding birds and migrating species. The Steele Family Limited Partnership acquisition will preserve and buffer high quality tallgrass prairie and, upon subsequent transfer, expand the Iowa Department of Natural Resources' 1,834-acre Waterman Prairie Wildlife Management Area. The project will build upon conservation successes by TNC and partners and enlarge a complex of conserved lands in the Waterman Creek Bird Conservation Area of the Little Sioux Watershed.

description.narrative: U.S. Fish and Wildlife (Service) staff will work cooperatively with the Association of Fish and Wildlife Agencies (AFWA) to develop and implement a range of science development, implementation, and coordination activities as described in the statement of work submitted with the application. Specifically, the Service participates in the semi-annual science coordination meetings with other federal agencies and AFWA to prioritize the activities of AFWA Science Coordination Team, based on input from various Service program areas and other agencies in their ongoing activities and science needs, review performance on recent activities, and revise tactics and strategies as necessary to meet goals. Based on identified goals and strategies from these coordination meetings, Service staff from various program areas work with the AFWA science staff to implement these science strategies via various cooperative Federal/State/Private teams and committees including the FWS Climate Change Team, the North American Bird Conservation Initiative, National Fish Habitat Action Plan, the AFWA Science and Research Committee, Partners in Amphibian and Reptile Conservation, the Endangered Species Task Force, and the National Invasive Species Council.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

description.narrative: In this phase partners will: 1) expand the Sustainable Grazing Network (SGN) to enroll and protect at least another 10,000 acres, 2) enhance at least 10,000 acres of SGN grasslands through improved grazing management, 3) restore at least 100 acres of degraded grasslands through shrub control, keyline or other intensive restoration techniques, 4) monitor grassland birds on SGN lands to assess impact, 5) train biologists in grassland bird monitoring and rangeland extension, 6) conduct outreach to SGN ranchers and managers using the results of our bird and vegetation monitoring to inform adaptive management, 7) permanently protect 514.5 acres of grasslands and foothill shrublands in Larimer County, Colorado from exurban development, and 8) assist local governments in conserving grassland birds through monitoring populations on protected open space lands. Through this multi-pronged approach, we aim to increase wintering populations of Sprague's Pipits and other high priority species, including Baird's Sparrow and Chestnut-collared Longspur, on SGN lands over the next 5-10 years and maintain breeding grassland bird populations in Larimer County, Colorado. The proposed activities will be conducted in cooperation with a broad network of regional and international partners for maximum impact, efficiency and synergy.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation

title.narrative: ACTIONABLE SCIENCE FOR GRASSLAND BIRD CO

description.narrative: The non-breeding season is pivotal to migratory grassland bird conservation, yet little is known of the limiting factors affecting non-breeding populations and how management actions can best mitigate threats to support stable grassland bird populations across the Chihuahuan Desert. This region is a mosaic of communal and private lands managed for agriculture and ranching. As such, identifying actionable conservation solutions that benefit grassland birds while sustaining local livelihoods is critical. Shrub encroachment represents a major threat to grasslands with economic and environmental consequences. However, uncertainty about the direction and magnitude of bird responses to shrubs across different scales could lead to inefficiencies in shrub management practices, with unintended negative consequences. Partners aim to understand the spatial and temporal scales at which habitat quality (i.e., shrubs) and climate (i.e., precipitation and temperature) drive population and movement dynamics of grassland birds across the Chihuahuan Desert. They will supplement existing grassland bird winter monitoring efforts throughout northern Mexico to determine seasonal shifts in occupancy dynamics in response to weather and management, focusing on Baird's and Grasshopper Sparrows. Grantees will continue establishing a network of automated radio telemetry (Motus) stations to link local and landscape-level habitat use with demographic and movement data that may underlie regional occupancy dynamics.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date
